intro: Tapinanthus keudelii, commonly known as the parasitic dodder, is a flowering plant belonging to the Orobanchaceae family. It is a hemiparasitic plant, meaning it can photosynthesize but also derives water and nutrients from its host through specialized root structures. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers and has a highly branched, vine-like appearance. It is native to tropical and subtropical regions of Africa and is often found growing on various shrubs and trees. Due to its parasitic nature, it can significantly affect the growth and survival of its host plants.
